fields.Title of Contribution: The intriguing spatial dynamics of vector-borne pathogen transmission with emergent vectors: while bloodmeals slow mosquito dispersal, host infections spread rapidly
fields.Description/Abstract:
A spatial, probabilistic model of vector disease transmission is considered
which focuses principally on the ensemble dynamics of mosquitoes. Mosquitoes
emerge and randomly explore their proximity to encounter and interact with
available hosts, which they may do multiple times for the transmission of
pathogens. The vector population is described as a density cloud that has
contact interactions with immobile hosts for realistic bloodmeals and potential
transmission events. This formalism is applied to a simple scenario where a
single cohort of mosquitoes emerge from a localized larval bed to encounter a
uniform background of infected hosts. They emerge, some bite and harbor
pathogens from infected hosts, and further disperse to potentially interact
with other hosts. A latency for vector infectiousness is included and the
mosquito population feeds and perishes according to classic malarial models.
Encountered hosts throughout are regarded as stationary in order to focus on 
the infectious dynamics of nocturnal, endophagic vectors. A longer-lived
infectious portion of the cohort if found to explore an extended region of
space about a larval bed, and whose distal distribution tails are able to
successfully infect hosts. Transmission is quite local up to and including this
extended region---that within reach of the infectious portion of the
cohort---and is otherwise essentially absent, demonstrating the locality and
the inherent heterogeneity of spatial transmission for a single, localized
cohort emergence. This transmission locality, or effective size of the patch
about the larval source where pathogens are transferred to and from the host
population, is found to vary with the reproductive number which sets the
intensity of transmission. Host infections are permitted to vary in space and
time with a progressing cohort's bloodmeals, and these feedings are shown to
slightly impede the cohort's progress in space, crowding the mosquitoes. While 
the bloodmeals slow the progress of the cohort into the community to a
subdiffusive rate, the spread of host infections happens superdiffusively,
accomplished by the early flights of the cohort. Numerics are carried out for a
finite population in two-dimensions, and with only four transmission parameters
the transmission theory simply connects with classical Ross/Macdonald dynamics.
